title: Autonomous Boat Robotic Arm - Object Retrieval and Delivery System for RoboBoat 2024
overview: The goal of this project was to design and build a robotic arm mounted on the autonomous boat Barka, capable of retrieving objects from the water and transporting them elsewhere.
The system was developed for the RoboBoat 2024 competition, where object pickup and delivery was one of the required missions.
The arm was designed with two degrees of freedom, and its end effector was implemented as a scoop-style gripper, allowing multiple objects to be collected in a single motion.
highlights: The entire robotic arm system - from concept through mechanical design, electronics, and embedded software â€” was independently designed and implemented by me end to end.
The end effector consists of a lightweight aluminum scoop with a mesh basket mounted at the end of the arm.
An initial proof-of-concept prototype was built using scrap steel parts, wooden rods, and mesh to validate the effectiveness and simplicity of the proposed solution.
Stepper motors with TMC2226 drivers were used as actuators; the motors were salvaged from a decommissioned 3D printer.

The arm homing and zero-position calibration were implemented using stall current sensing in the TMC2226 drivers, utilizing the integrated current shunt; this allowed sensorless referencing without limit switches.

A dedicated test setup was created to evaluate stepper motors and stepstick drivers, followed by the development of an STM32F446-based driver capable of controlling multiple TMC2226 modules using DIR/STEP signals and UART for runtime configuration.
A dedicated test stand was used to characterize stall detection behavior, tune driver parameters, and develop robust homing logic, resulting in reliable and repeatable initialization code.
The final robotic arm structure was manufactured using a combination of 3D-printed components and aluminum parts, and then mounted on the autonomous boat Barka.
Torque from the stepper motors was transmitted to the joints using toothed belt drives, providing mechanical decoupling and flexible motor placement.
The arm was fully integrated with the boat's control software, supporting both remote manual control and autonomous operation modes.
results: The robotic arm successfully demonstrated reliable object retrieval during testing and competition runs.
The scoop-based end effector proved effective for collecting multiple floating objects in a single maneuver.
Limitations included relatively slow actuation speed and limited positioning precision due to the open-loop stepper-based control.
Future improvements could include closed-loop position feedback, weight reduction, and a more compact folding mechanism for transport.
